question: What can I do about middle back pain?
question_content: I have a chronic pain in the middle of my back. It feels like a sore knotted muscle right next to the spine or disc.  I don’t know the name or number of the bone/area, but it seems to be right at the bottom of my ribcage at the smallest part of my waist.  I think I tend to have more of an hour glass figure, but with too much weight, I can still have the stomach-hip ratio of an apple shape, which probably means the excess belly weight is hurting my back. In addition, having poor posture is probably not helping, either.  The pain is most noticeable when I am under stress. I notice when I am under a certain weight, it goes away. I know the obvious answer is to loose weight and improve posture (in progress; already lost 20lbs).  I’ve had this for a few years now and massaging doesn’t seem to get it out.  Could this be something serious? Should I check into a chiropractor?  My doctor prescribed me Mobic (Meloxicam), but only based on what I told him (he didn’t physically check it out).  And are there any type of exercises for the lower back that can help? Stretches? Any comment, advice would help.

answers.answer_content:
Lumbar spine.  Common.  Any part of the spine that hasn't got a rib attached to it is - is your lumbar spine.  The lower part.  Emotions, some people may disagree but I believe can manifest themselves into something more physical.

Poor posture is 90% of NSLBP.  Non-specific lower back pain.  

You need to retrain your core muscles - I'm not talking superficial here - I'm talking your transversus abdominals.  You must re-learn to fire these when moving.  

So you have a weak core and I bet tight hips / hamstrings.  Stretches are excellent.  Search for "hip openers" on you-tube - classic Yoga stretches.  

Forget massages - waste of time.  You need strengthening - not lengthening :)

You seem to know what to do.  Lose weight, start some with some stretches and then I would definitely start on some resistance type training.  Proper strength training - do not do body-building training.  Body building is all about appearance and not ability.  

You need proper strength training where we target the postural deeper muscles.  

Hope this helps, best of luck!

I completely understand your lower back pain. I suffer from chronic pain including lower back pain in my lumbar spine. This is a result of RSD and Fibromyalgia along with other medical conditions. So reading your symptoms and how bad your pain is, I think that you might have something going on that needs to be detected by an MRI. I think you should see a back specialist. I think this because you say you didn't fall and it hurts when you bend over and sneeze. I really do hope you will get an appointment with a specialist soon. It is really the best way to find out if there is a pinched nerve, a herniated disc, mild arthritis in your lower spine (as they've told me), or something that can be easily treated.
